instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> voltage jumping around
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - looks like it may have been cleaned, so no hints. Green light on charger. No fan spin.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 16.6v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3,4v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> switching between 3.36 and 3.41v


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - multimeter (fluke) goes crazy get lightning bolt icon indicates 3.4v-34.4v not seen this before

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> switching between 0.2 and 3,3v with readings inbetween.


<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

pin 23 8.49v
pin 4 (enable) 0v <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> measures 0.3ohm
pin 21 (enable) switching between 1 and 3.3v
pin 12 <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> switching between 1 and 3.3v

checked <RESISTOR>R5198</RESISTOR> was showing 68k not 100k changed it, but after still remained 68k

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.371v @<RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> switching between 1 and 3v <RESISTOR>R5185</RESISTOR> 8.9k


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> diode mode to ground on <CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR> 1.4v

any ideas ? thank you for you time

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> voltage jumping around
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is not stable. This sucks as this could be an SMC issue or it could be that <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes low. It could be that <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> or s0 is shorted. Check for short to GND on <RESISTOR>R8000</RESISTOR>,8011,8050,8020. Also check for shorts on all 5V busses, S3 and S0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> voltage jumping around
threads.message:
thank you duke.

<RESISTOR>R8000</RESISTOR>, reading shows no short on pads 1 & 2 0.9v drop to ground in diode mode.

Same for <RESISTOR>R8011</RESISTOR> 

<RESISTOR>R8050</RESISTOR> measures 0.4ohm as resistance, 0.941v drop to ground in diode mode. 
When board is powered voltage on <RESISTOR>R8050</RESISTOR> jumps between 0.4 and 0.6v

<RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> 0.731v voltage drop to ground in diode mode 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> measured at <RESISTOR>R2042</RESISTOR> is jummping from 1 to 3v
has 0.429 v drop to gnd

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> measured at probe point 178 is jumping 1 to 3v, shows OL v drop to ground.

<RESISTOR>R8141</RESISTOR> pin 1 has solid 3.4 PP3v42, Pin 2 has jumping.1v to 3v.measures 93.6k in resistance, 
pin 1 0.731v drop to gnd
pin 2 0.401 drop to gnd.

Measuring other rails voltage drop to gnd:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 1.4v drop to gnd @ <CAPACITOR>C7600</CAPACITOR>, 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 1.2v drop to gnd @<RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.429 @<RESISTOR>R2042</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0.369 @<CAPACITOR>C3510</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 0.329 @<RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 0.452 @<RESISTOR>R2040</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 0.319 @<RESISTOR>R2041</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> 0.349 @<CAPACITOR>C5480</CAPACITOR>

So with no shorts to ground must it be the SMC ?
Can I try running a wire for PP3V42 to pin 12 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>) and see what happens ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> voltage jumping around
threads.message:
I would go for the SMC first. I have a feeling this one is going to suck :(

Have you tried connecting a charged battery and see if voltages are stable and if it charges?
